{{Nowrap|[[Kershaw County, South Carolina]]}} | party = [[Conservative Party (South Carolina)|Conservative Party]] | otherparty = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Mary Boykin Chesnut|Mary Boykin Miller]]|April 23, 1840}} | allegiance = {{flag|Confederate States|1865}} | branch = {{army|CSA|size=23px}} | serviceyears = 1861-1865 | rank = [[File:Confederate States of America General.png|30px]] [[Brigadier general|Brigadier-General]] | battles = [[American Civil War]]
* [[Battle of Fort Sumter]] * [[First Battle of Manassas]] * [[Battle of Tulifinny]] }} '''James Chesnut Jr.''' (January 18, 1815 – February 1, 1885) was an American politician who served as a Deputy from [[South Carolina]] to the [[Provisional Congress of the Confederate States]] from 1861 to 1862. He also served as a senior [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] of the [[Confederate States Army]] in the [[Eastern Theater of the American Civil War|Eastern Theater]] of the [[American Civil War]]. Chesnut, a lawyer prominent in [[South Carolina]] state politics, served as a Democratic [[United States Senator|senator]] in 1858-60, where he proved moderate on the slavery question. But on Lincoln’s election in 1860, Chesnut resigned from the U.S. Senate and took part in the South Carolina secession convention, later helping to draft the [[Confederate States Constitution]]. As aide to General [[P.G.T. Beauregard]], he ordered the [[Battle of Fort Sumter|firing on Fort Sumter]] and served at [[First Manassas]]. Later he was aide to [[Jefferson Davis]] and promoted to Brigadier-General. Chesnut returned to law practice after the war. His wife was [[Mary Boykin Chesnut]], whose published diaries reflect the Chesnuts' busy social life and prominent friends such as [[John Bell Hood]], [[Louis T. Wigfall]], [[Wade Hampton III]], and Jefferson Davis. ==Early life and education== James Chesnut Jr., was born the youngest of fourteen children and the only (surviving) son of James Chesnut Sr. (1775–1866) and his wife, Mary Cox (1777–1864){{cite web|title=Papers of the Cox and Chesnut Families, 1792-1858|url=http://scmemory.org/collection/papers-of-the-cox-and-chesnut-families-1792-1858/|website=South Carolina Digital Library|accessdate=6 October 2014}} on [[Mulberry Plantation (James and Mary Boykin Chesnut House)|Mulberry Plantation]] near [[Camden, South Carolina]]. Chesnut Sr. was one of the wealthiest [[Plantations in the American South|planters]] in the South, who owned 448 slaves and many large plantations totaling nearly five square miles before the outbreak of the Civil War. Chesnut Jr. graduated from the law department of the College of New Jersey (now [[Princeton University]]) in 1835, and initially rose to prominence in [[South Carolina]] state politics. ==Political career== [[Admission to the bar|Admitted to the bar]] in 1837, Chesnut Jr. commenced practice that year in Camden. He was later elected as a member of the [[South Carolina House of Representatives]] (1840–52) and the [[South Carolina Senate]] (1852–58, serving as its president 1856–58). He was a delegate to the [[Nashville Convention|southern convention]] at [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 1850. In 1858 Chesnut was elected by the [[South Carolina Legislature]] to the [[U.S. Senate]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to replace [[Josiah J. Evans]]. He served there for two years alongside Senator [[James Henry Hammond]] of South Carolina. Although a defender of [[slavery]] and [[states' rights]], Chesnut opposed the re-opening of the [[Atlantic slave trade|African slave trade]] and was not as staunch a [[secessionist]] as most of the South Carolinian politicians. Moderate in his political views, he believed in extending protections for slavery's westward expansion while remaining within the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]]. But the political atmosphere tightened towards the [[Presidential election of 1860|Presidential Election of 1860]], since the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and its presidential candidate, [[Abraham Lincoln]], opposed slavery. After the results of the election were known, Chesnut decided that he could no longer stay in his office in the Senate.Scarborough, ''Masters of the Big House'', pp. 277 and 289, Cauthen, ''South Carolina Goes to War'', pp. 49–50, Sinha, ''The Counterrevolution of the Slavery'', pp. 134, 138, 176–7. Shortly after Lincoln's election, he was the first Southern senator to withdraw from the Senate, on November 10, 1860. (He was [[Expulsion from the United States Congress|expelled]] ''in absentia'' from the Senate the next year.) Chesnut participated in the South Carolina secession convention in December 1860 and was subsequently elected to the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States. He was a member of the committee which drafted the Confederate States Constitution. ==American Civil War== [[File:James Chesnut, Jr.jpg|thumb|left|110px|Col. James Chesnut, [[Circa|c.]] 1862]] In the spring of 1861, he served as an [[aide-de-camp]] to General [[P.G.T. Beauregard]] and was sent by the general to demand the surrender of [[Fort Sumter]] in [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]]. After the commander of the fort, Major [[Robert Anderson (Civil War)|Robert Anderson]] of the [[U.S. Army]] declined to surrender, Chesnut gave orders to the nearby Fort Johnson to open fire on Fort Sumter. In consequence the first shots of the Civil War were fired, on April 12, 1861.Williams, ''Beauregard'', pp. 57–58. In the summer of 1861 Chesnut also took part in the [[First Battle of Bull Run|First Battle of Manassas]] as an aide-de-camp to Beauregard. In 1862 Chesnut served as a member of the South Carolina's Executive Council and the Chief of the Department of the Military of South Carolina. Later in the war he served the Confederate Army as a [[colonel]] and an aide to [[President of the Confederate States of America|Confederate President]] [[Jefferson Davis]]. In 1864 he was promoted to [[Brigadier General (CSA)|brigadier general]] and given command of South Carolina reserve forces until the end of the war. He was third in command of the confederate forces at the [[Battle of Tulifinny]]. He was in overall command before the arrival of Maj. Gen. [[Samuel Jones (Confederate Army officer)|Samuel Jones]] and later Brig. Gen. [[Lucius Jeremiah Gartrell|Lucius Gartrell]]. After the war, he returned to the practice of law in Camden and formed the [[Conservative Party (South Carolina)|Conservative Party]]. ==Personal life== Although James Chesnut Jr. was the only son, his father had given him little of his extensive property. Because his father lived to the age of 90 and gave his son but a small allowance, the son James had to live mainly on his law practice. The Chesnut fortune declined in the course of the war and thus, after his father died in 1866, Chesnut inherited little more than the extensive debts that encumbered the Mulberry and Sandy Hill plantations.Muhlenfeld, ''Mary Boykin Chesnut'', ''passim''. Chesnut married seventeen-year-old [[Mary Chesnut|Mary Boykin Miller]] (1823–86), on April 23, 1840. She later became well known for her book on life during the Civil War, published as a diary but revised extensively from 1881 to 1886. The daughter of U.S. Senator [[Stephen Decatur Miller]] (1788–1838) and Mary Boykin (1804–85), she was well-educated and intelligent and took part in her husband's career. The Chesnuts' marriage was at times stormy due to difference in temperament (she was hot-tempered and passionate and came occasionally to regard her husband as cool and reserved). Their companionship was mostly warm and affectionate but they had no children.Chesnut, ''Mary Chesnut's Civil War'', ''passim''. The couple resided at [[Chesnut Cottage]] in Columbia during the Civil War period.{{Cite web | title = Chesnut Cottage, Richland County (1718 Hampton St., Columbia) | work = National Register Properties in South Carolina | publisher = South Carolina Department of Archives and History | url = http://www.nationalregister.sc.gov/richland/S10817740016/index.htm | accessdate =2014-01-07}} As Mary Chesnut described in depth in her diary, the Chesnuts had a wide circle of friends and acquaintances in the society of the South and the Confederacy. Among their friends were, for example, Confederate general [[John Bell Hood]], ex-Governor [[John L. Manning]], Confederate general and politician [[John S. Preston]] and his wife Caroline, Confederate general and politician [[Wade Hampton III]], Confederate politician [[Clement Claiborne Clay|Clement C. Clay]] and his wife [[Virginia Clay-Clopton|Virginia]], and Confederate general and politician [[Louis T. Wigfall]] and his wife Charlotte. The Chesnuts were intimate family friends of President Jefferson Davis and his wife [[Varina Howell]]. James Chesnut was also a first cousin of fellow Confederate general [[Zachariah C. Deas]]. ==Death== James Chesnut was "regarded as an amiable, modest gentleman of decent parts [gifts]",Hammond, ''Secret And Sacred'', p. 214. who performed his duties with ability and dignity both in political and military life. He died at home in Camden in 1885; interment was in Chesnut Family Cemetery, [[Kershaw County, South Carolina]]. ==See also== * [[List of American Civil War generals (Confederate)]] * [[List of United States Senators expelled or censured]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * Cauthen, Charles E.: ''South Carolina Goes to War: 1860–1865''. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press 1950. * Chesnut, Mary Boykin: ''Mary Chesnut's Civil War''. New Haven: Yale University Press 1981), ed. C. Vann Woodward. * Eicher, John H. & Eicher, David J.: ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. * Hammond, James Henry: ''Secret And Sacred: The Diaries of James Henry Hammond, a Southern Slaveholder''. Edited by Carol Bleser. New York: Oxford University Press 1988. * Muhlenfeld, Elisabeth: ''Mary Boykin Chesnut: A Biography''. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1992. * Scarborough, William Kaufman: ''The Masters of the Big House: Elite Slaveholders of the Mid-Nineteenth-Century South''. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 2003. * Sifakis, Stewart: ''Who Was Who in the Civil War.'' New York: Facts On File, 1988. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-1055-4}}. * Sinha, Manisha, ''The Counterrevolution of Slavery: Politics and Ideology in Antebellum South Carolina''. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press, 2000. * [[Ezra J. Warner (historian)|Warner, Ezra J.]]: ''Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959. {{ISBN|978-0-8071-0823-9}}. * Williams, T. Harry: ''Beauregard: Napoleon in Gray''. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press 1955. {{Div col end}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | author=Koivusalo, Anna | title=The Man Who Started the American Civil War: Southern Honor, Emotion, and James Chesnut, Jr. | publisher=University of Helsinki | year=2017 | isbn=978-951-51-3073-0 | laysummary=http://urn.fi/URN:ISBN:978-951-51-3073-0 | type=Ph.D. thesis }} ==External links== * {{Find a Grave|8575}} * [http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/chertov-childers.html#118.03.73 James Chesnut Jr.] at ''[[The Political Graveyard]]'' * {{CongBio|c000348}} {{Navboxes |title=Offices and distinctions |list1= {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{U.S. Senator box|state=South Carolina|class=3|before=[[Arthur P. Hayne]]|after=vacant |alongside=[[James Henry Hammond|James H. Hammond]]|years=1858–1860}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=Deputy from [[South Carolina]] to the
[[Provisional Congress of the Confederate States]]|years=1861–1862|before=New constituency|after=Constituency abolished}} {{s-end}} }} {{Navboxes |title=Articles related to James Chesnut Jr. |list1= {{CSProvisionalConstitutionSig}} {{Confederate States Constitution signatories}} {{USSenSC}} }} {{Portalbar|American Civil War|Biography|Politics|South Carolina}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chesnut, James Jr.}} [[Category:1815 births]] [[Category:1885 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Burials in South Carolina]] [[Category:Confederate States Army brigadier generals]] [[Category:Conservative Party (South Carolina) politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Party United States Senators]] [[Category:Deputies and delegates to the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States]] [[Category:Expelled United States Senators]] [[Category:Members of the South Carolina House of Representatives]] [[Category:People of South Carolina in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Signers of the Confederate States Constitution]] [[Category:Signers of the Provisional Constitution of the Confederate States]] [[Category:South Carolina Democrats]] [[Category:South Carolina state senators]] [[Category:United States Senators from South Carolina]]

'''Jeffrey Hunker''' (1957-2013) was an American cyber security consultant and writer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/profile/jeffrey-hunker |title=Jeffrey Hunker |publisher=The Guardian |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref>
==Biography== Hunker received his [[bachelor's degree]] from [[Harvard College]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from [[Harvard Business School]]. He joined the [[Boston Consulting Group]] before becoming an advisor in the [[United States Department of Commerce|Department of Commerce]] and the founding director of the Critical Infrastructure Assurance Office (later subsumed by the [[Department of Homeland Security]] [[National Protection and Programs Directorate]]). This led him to serve on the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] as the Senior Director for Critical Infrastructure.
Hunker was also a Vice President at [[Kidder, Peabody & Co.]], [[Dean (education)|dean]] of the [[Heinz College]] at [[Carnegie Mellon]], and a member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]]. He is credited with coining the term [[cyberinfrastructure]] and has worked closely with [[Richard A. Clarke]] on [[cyberterrorism]] issues. Hunker's research is primarily concerned with Homeland and Information Security. Prof. Hunker was also the Carnegie Mellon Representation for the [[Institute for Information Infrastructure Protection]].
In 2008 Hunker was charged three times with [[driving under the influence]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08240/907173-53.stm |title=CMU professor charged with drunken driving three times in past eight days - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=2008-08-27 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> followed by another incident on Thanksgiving 2009. In May 2010 Hunker pleaded guilty to these four drunken driving charges and was sentenced to 3 to 6 months in jail.<ref>[http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22599352/detail.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100327231858/http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22599352/detail.html |date=March 27, 2010 }}</ref> He was paroled at sentencing and was sentenced to 24 months probation.<ref>http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/s_680998.html{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This sentence was terminated early on June 2, 2011.<ref>(see CC2008-17527,CC2008-17526,CC2008-17530,CC2009-17737, Judge Kevin Sasinoski, Court of Common Pleas of Allegheny County, 436 Grant Street, Pittsburgh PA 15219, Court of Clerks Kate Barkman, 412 350 2910)</ref>
In 2010 his book ''Creeping Failure: How We Broke the Internet and What We Can Do to Fix It'' <ref>{{cite web|author=Jeffrey Hunker |url=http://www.mcclelland.com/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780771041488 |title=Books | Creeping Failure by Jeffrey Hunker |publisher=McClelland.com |date=2010-08-24 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> was published by McClelland and Stewart, a division of Random House.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.com/catalog/display.pperl?isbn=9780771041488 |title=Creeping Failure by Jeffrey Hunker - Book - eBook |publisher=Random House |date= |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> Creeping Failure is a Scientific American magazine Recommended Book.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wong |first=Kate |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=recommended-nov-10 |title=Recommended: The Princeton Field Guide to Dinosaurs |publisher=Scientific American |date=2013-06-25 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> In 2011 a second edition was released. Also in 2010 he was co-editor of Insider Threats in Cyber Security <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/50872833/Insider-Threats-in-Cyber-Security |title=Insider Threats in Cyber Security |publisher=Docstoc.com |date= |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref> and his article (co-authored with Christian Probst)The Risk of Risk Analysis and its Relation to the Economics of Insider Threats appears in The Economics of Information Security and Privacy.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/wt54g6h3821g886g/ |title=The Risk of Risk Analysis And its Relation to the Economics of Insider Threats |date= |accessdate=2013-06-29 |doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-6967-5_14 |journal=Economics of Information Security and Privacy |pages=279–299}}</ref>
Until 2013, he was Visiting Scholar in the Computer Science Department at the University of California, Davis,<ref>(www.cs.ucdavis.edu)</ref> and was also consulting with a major philanthropic foundation in Pittsburgh. His most recent books are, as co-editor and contributor, Insider Threats in Cyber Security (Springer, 2010), and Cybersecurity: Shared Risks, Shared Responsibilities (Carolina Academic Press, 2012). Dr. Hunker died on May 31, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmerhermanfuneralhome.com/obits/obituary.php?id=305534 |title=Dr Jeffrey Hunker, Ph.D Obituary - Elmer L Herman Funeral Home |publisher=Elmerhermanfuneralhome.com |date=2013-05-31 |accessdate=2013-06-29}}</ref>

'''Jos Devlies''' is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[Medical Doctor]] and an expert in [[eHealth]] at the [[European Institute for Health Records]] (EuroRec).
He graduated in Family Medicine at the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven|Catholic University of Leuven]] in 1969 and in [[Occupational therapist|Occupational Healthcare]] at the [[University of Ghent]] in 1972. In addition he obtained a degree in the Management of Healthcare Data in 2003.
Jos Devlies worked full-time as a [[General Practitioner]], for over 30 years, and worked for several years part-time in Occupational Healthcare, especially in the [[public sector]], he started to be an entrepreneur. He has founded and chaired several companies. He is co-author of the Belgian [[certification]] criteria for [[General practitioner|GP]] [[Electronic health record|EHR]] systems. Together with [[Georges De Moor]] and [[Geert Thienpont]], he is the author of the 2006 ''eHealth strategy and implementation activities in Belgium'' report.<ref>[http://www.ehealth-era.org/database/documents/ERA_Reports/Belgium_eHealth-ERA_country-report_final_30-06-2007.pdf eHealth strategy and implementation activities in Belgium] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5v5DwJAUQ?url=http://www.ehealth-era.org/database/documents/ERA_Reports/Belgium_eHealth-ERA_country-report_final_30-06-2007.pdf |date=19 December 2010 }}</ref>
==Sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080905224826/http://mednet2007.com/whoiswho_mednet.pdf MedNet 2007] * [http://www.eurorec.org/executive.cfm?actief=body EuroRec] * [http://www.health.fgov.be/EMDMI/nl/Technische%20gevolgen/technisc.htm Technische gevolgen van de functies van het Electronisch Medisch Dossier] (Dutch)
==See also== * [[Belgian Medical Informatics Association]]

Robbins'''<ref name="LinkedIn">{{cite web |url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/joshuawrobbins |title=Josh Robbins |publisher=[[LinkedIn]] |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}<!-- Admissible for non-exceptional claims per [[WP:ABOUTSELF]] --></ref> (born January 12, 1983<ref name="WhoSay">{{cite web |url=http://www.whosay.com/imstilljosh/bio |title=Josh Robbins |publisher=[[WhoSay]] |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}<!-- Admissible for non-exceptional claims per [[WP:ABOUTSELF]] --></ref> in [[Jackson, Tennessee]])<ref name="WhoSay"/><ref name="TheBody 3">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebody.com/content/71013/this-positive-life-newly-living-with-hiv-josh-robb.html?getPage=3 |title=Newly living with HIV, Josh Robbins is "Still Josh" — and still an Advocate (page 3) |work=This Positive Life |publisher=[[TheBody.com]] |date=March 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="O&AN 2010-12-01">{{cite news |url=http://www.outandaboutnashville.com/story/holiday-memories-josh-robbins |title=Holiday memories: Josh Robbins |work=Out & About Nashville |date=December 1, 2010 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> is an American [[HIV/AIDS]] activist,<ref name="POZ 100, 2013">{{cite news |url=http://www.poz.com/articles/poz100_p_r_2806_24776.shtml#Josh_Robbins |title=The POZ 100: P–R |work=[[POZ (magazine)|POZ]] |date=December 2013 |accessdate=December 28, 2014}}</ref> blogger,<ref name="POZ 100, 2013"/> [[talent agent]],<ref name="IMDb">{{IMDb name|3865899}}</ref><ref name="About.com">{{cite web |url=http://aids.about.com/b/2014/01/20/people-to-watch-josh-robbins-imstilljosh-com.htm |title=People to Watch: Josh Robbins @imstilljosh.com |date=October 29, 2014 |accessdate=December 28, 2014 |publisher=About Health }}</ref> writer, and [[social media marketing|social media marketer]].<ref name="POZ 100, 2013"/> His work has been featured on ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', [[Human Rights Campaign]], [[Healthline]], ''[[POZ (magazine)|POZ]]'' and a myriad of additional publications. Robbins was named to the ''POZ'' 100 List in 2013.<ref name="POZ 100, 2013"/>
== Advocacy == Before his HIV diagnosis, Robbins was raising awareness about HIV in the [[LGBT community]] and fundraising for the [[AIDS service organization]] Nashville CARES.<ref name="POZ 100, 2013"/> He was also a volunteer for the [[HVTN 505]] clinical vaccine trial.<ref name="POZ 100, 2013"/><ref name="ISJ About">{{cite web |url=http://www.imstilljosh.com/about/ |title=About I'm Still Josh |publisher=I'm Still Josh |date=May 25, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> He has been described as "one of a growing legion of bloggers who are breathing life into HIV activism".<ref name="About.com"/>
Robbins published a video on [[YouTube]] of being told of his HIV diagnosis in January 2012,<ref name="ISJ About"/><ref>{{YouTube|pjwrRou8--0|I'm HIV Positive I just found out I'm HIV + ... now what? I'm still Josh}}. Recorded January 24, 2012; uploaded February 28, 2012; accessed December 28, 2014.</ref> after revealing his HIV status on [[Facebook]].<ref name="TheBody 2">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebody.com/content/71013/this-positive-life-newly-living-with-hiv-josh-robb.html?getPage=2 |title=Newly living with HIV, Josh Robbins is "Still Josh" — and still an Advocate (page 2) |work=This Positive Life |publisher=[[TheBody.com]] |date=March 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> Robbins also hosts the weekly digital series, ''HIV Video Minute with Josh Robbins'', and created the "Ask HIV" iPhone app.<ref name="Ask HIV">{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/ask-hiv/id946510091?mt=8 |title=Ask HIV |publisher=[[iTunes Store]] |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=December 28, 2014 }}</ref>
=== Social media === Robbins uses digital and [[social media]] to advocate for HIV education to reduce [[social stigma#HIV|stigma]] and [[discrimination against people with HIV/AIDS]].<ref name="ABC">{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/hiv-hot-spots-stark-reminder-deadly-disease/story?id=20707963&singlePage=true |title=HIV hot-spots a stark reminder of deadly disease |work=''[[Good Morning America]]'' |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=November 1, 2013 |accessdate=December 28, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Healthline interview 2014-11-26">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthline.com/health/hiv-aids/living-with-hiv-josh |title=Life with HIV: The Angry Activist Tells All |publisher=[[Healthline]] |date=November 26, 2014 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> He creates video content for online distribution and was recognized on the "Best HIV Videos of 2013" list by Healthline noting his use of "artistic features such as [[letterboxing (filming)|wide letter boxing]], captions, and double speed filming".<ref name="Healthline videos 2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthline.com/health-slideshow/best-videos-hiv-aids#12 |title=11 Best HIV Videos of 2013 |publisher=[[Healthline]] |date=November 20, 2013 |accessdate=December 28, 2014 }}</ref> In 2014, Robbins introduced the "HIV Video Minute with Josh Robbins" digital video series, licensed to ''HIV+'' magazine.<ref name="IMDb"/><ref name="HIV Video Minute">{{cite web |url=http://www.hivplusmag.com/hiv-plus-video-minute |title=HIV Video Minute |work=HIV+ |accessdate=December 28, 2014 }}</ref>
=== Blogger and author === In 2012, Robbins launched his blog focusing on encouraging those [[HIV-positive people|living with HIV/AIDS]], described as a combination of "fact-based reportage and highly personal social blogging — in a way that [is] both insightful and utterly engaging".<ref name="About.com"/>
Robbins is a published writer for health-related websites, including the "Healthline HIV Influencer Honors" for 2013<ref name="Healthline influencers 2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthline.com/health-slideshow/hiv-awareness-awards |title=HIV Influencers Honors |publisher=[[Healthline]] |date=November 27, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 |archivedate=December 8, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208095611/http://www.healthline.com/health-slideshow/hiv-awareness-awards }}<!-- Archived version only works with CSS disabled --></ref> and 2014<ref name="Healthline influencers 2014">{{cite web |url=http://www.healthline.com/health-slideshow/hiv-awareness-awards |title=HIV Influencers Honors — The Top 11 Influential Voices in HIV/AIDS for 2014 |publisher=[[Healthline]] |date=December 4, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 |archivedate=December 26, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226033119/http://www.healthline.com/health-slideshow/hiv-awareness-awards }}<!-- Archived version only works with CSS disabled --></ref> and the 2014 "HIV Top Voices" list for [[TrialReach]].<ref name="TrialReach voices 2014">{{cite web |url=http://blog.trialreach.com/2014/05/01/top-hiv-voices-2014/ |title=Top HIV Voices 2014 |publisher=[[TrialReach]] |date=May 1, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}<!-- Archived version only works with CSS disabled --></ref> In 2014, Robbins self-published: ''HIV Won't Kill Me: Encouragement eBook''<ref name="B00INKSP4W">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pHbxAgAAQBAJ |title=HIV Won't Kill Me: Encouragement eBook |author=Josh Robbins |publisher=imstilljosh.com |asin=B00INKSP4W |date=February 25, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> He also published ''Social Media Is Not Prison, So Unlock Yourself: Tips from a Social Media HIV Activist''.<ref name="B00P0EYMIW">{{cite book |url=http://www.thebrandagement.com/?attachment_id=6747 |title=Social Media Is Not Prison, So Unlock Yourself: Tips from a Social Media HIV Activist |author=Josh Robbins |publisher=imstilljosh.com |asin=B00P0EYMIW |date=October 29, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref>
In 2014, Robbins created an iPhone application called Ask HIV,<ref name="Ask HIV"/> described by [[Product Hunt]] as "an HIV/AIDS hotline on your iPhone".<ref name="Product Hunt Ask HIV">{{cite web |url=https://www.producthunt.com/posts/ask-hiv |title=Ask HIV |publisher=[[Product Hunt]] |date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref>
== Entrepreneur == Robbins is a veteran [[talent agent]], owning and operating BNA Talent Group with niche divisions for actors, hosts and children<ref name="MusicRow 2009-09-15">{{cite news |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2009/09/nichols-performs-for-dalai-lama-bna-talent-group-opens/ |title=Nichols performs for Dalai Lama & BNA Talent Group opens |work=[[MusicRow]] |date=September 15, 2009 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="BNA Talent Group">{{cite web |url=http://bnatalent.com/about-nashville-talent-agency-bna-talent-group/ |title=About Nashville talent agency BNA Talent Group |publisher=BNA Talent Group |date=November 19, 2012 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="WBIR">{{cite news |url=http://www.wbir.com/news/article/277031/2/Businesses-step-up-efforts-to-attract-LGBT-customers |title=Businesses step up efforts to attract LGBT customers |publisher=[[WBIR-TV]] |date=June 9, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> and a division managing brands called The BRANDagement at BNA Talent Group.<ref name="BNA Talent Group"/><ref name="BRANDagement">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebrandagement.com/#section-our-team |title=Our team |publisher=The BRANDagement at BNA Talent Group |date=November 9, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> His clients have appeared in studio feature films and on television.<ref name="IMDb"/><ref name="MusicRow 2011-01-14">{{cite news |url=http://www.musicrow.com/2011/01/bna-talent-signs-lopez-and-tallant/ |title=BNA Talent signs Lopez and Tallant |work=[[MusicRow]] |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.towleroad.com/2014/08/country-musician-rebranded-straightwashed-for-heterosexual-audience.html |title=Country musician Josey Greenwell rebranded, 'straightwashed' for heterosexual audience |work=[[Towleroad]] |date=August 20, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bleedingcool.com/2010/09/19/is-terry-gilliam-currently-in-production-on-something-called-the-legend-of-talladega/ |title=Is Terry Gilliam currently in production on something called ''The Legend of Talladega''? |work=[[Bleeding Cool]] |date=September 19, 2010 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> He also works with companies interested in casting models and actors aimed at LGBT consumers.<ref name="WBIR"/> As a business professional, Robbins is vocal for LGBT issues in the workplace.<ref name="Viacom 2013-07-10">{{cite news |url=http://blog.viacom.com/2013/07/open-for-business-panel-gathers-professionals-to-discuss-lgbt-issues/ |title=CMT ‘open for Business’ panel addresses LGBT issues, future of the workplace |publisher=[[Viacom]] |date=July 10, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref>
== Personal life == Robbins identifies as an [[coming out|out]] gay man<ref name="TheBody 1">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebody.com/content/71013/this-positive-life-newly-living-with-hiv-josh-robb.html |title=Newly living with HIV, Josh Robbins is "Still Josh" — and still an Advocate (page 1) |work=This Positive Life |publisher=[[TheBody.com]] |date=March 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> and is open about his HIV-positive status.<ref name="ISJ About"/><ref name="ABC"/><ref name="TheBody 1"/><ref name="O&AN 2012-03-05">{{cite news |url=http://www.outandaboutnashville.com/story/josh-robbins-comes-out |title=Josh Robbins comes OUT |work=Out & About Nashville |date=March 5, 2012 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> He supports [[AIDS service organization|HIV/AIDS organizations]] including Nashville CARES<ref name="Nashville CARES 2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.nashvillecares.org/about/publications/sm_files/2013%20Annual%20Report%20Electronic.pdf |title=Annual Report 2012–2013 |publisher=Nashville CARES |format=PDF |date=2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="TheBody 4">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebody.com/content/71013/this-positive-life-newly-living-with-hiv-josh-robb.html?getPage=4 |title=Newly living with HIV, Josh Robbins is "Still Josh" — and still an Advocate (page 4) |work=This Positive Life |publisher=[[TheBody.com]] |date=March 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 29, 2014 }}</ref> and the [[HIV Vaccine Trials Network]]. He was diagnosed with HIV during his participation in the [[HVTN 505]] clinical trial<ref name="ISJ About"/><ref name="AP 2013-04-25">{{cite web |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/another-hiv-vaccine-fails-govt-halts-us-study |title=Latest HIV vaccine doesn't work; govt halts study |work=The Big Story |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=April 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> though he explained that his infection was not a result of the vaccine.<ref name="O&AN 2013-04-29">{{cite news |url=http://www.outandaboutnashville.com/story/national-hiv-vaccine-trial-hvtn-505 |title=National HIV vaccine trial, HVTN 505, immunizations stopped |work=Out & About Nashville |date=April 29, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2014 }}</ref> Robbins has a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in Journalism, Advertising and Marketing from [[Middle Tennessee State University]]<ref name="LinkedIn"/> and lives in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="WhoSay"/><ref name="ABC"/>
