{{Infobox person |name=Raghid El-Solh |image=Raghid El-Solh.jpg |birth_date = 7 July 1942 |birth_place = Beirut |death_date = 1 February 2018 |nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] |occupation = writer, researcher }}
'''Raghid Kazem El-Solh''' (7 July 1942 – 1 February 2018) was a Lebanese writer and researcher in international and Arab regional relations as well as democracy issues.<ref>{{cite web |title=Raghid El-Solh Obituary |publisher=The Times |date=February 4, 2018 |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/thetimes-uk/obituary.aspx?n=raghid-kazim-el-solh&pid=183948077}}</ref> He published several books about international relations, the Arab region and democracy. He was a regular contributor to several publications including the London-based pan-Arab Al-Hayat newspaper, and was a regular lecturer, political commentator and a consultant for the UN and other organizations.
Raghid was the son of [[Kazem El-Solh]], a former member of [[Lebanese Parliament]] and a former Lebanese ambassador to Iraq. He hails from a prominent [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni Muslim]] family which gave Lebanon four prime ministers: [[Riad Solh]], [[Sami as-Solh|Sami Solh]], [[Takieddine Solh]] and [[Rachid Solh]].
==Career== Raghid Kazem El-Solh earned a B.A. in political science from the [[American University of Beirut]] (1964), a M.Sc. in political science from the School of Oriental & African Studies at the University of London (1978) and a PhD in politics and international relations from St. Antony's College, Faculty of Social Science, at the [[University of Oxford]] (1986).
He is the author of several books including: Peaceful Settlement and Arab Unity (1980), Lebanon on the Road to the Future (1979), Oman and the South-Eastern Shore of Arabia (Archive documents on the history of the Arab world series) (1997), The Sultanate of Oman 1939-1945 (2000), The Sultanate of Oman 1914-1918 (2000), The Sultanate of Oman 1918-1939: Part I (2000), The Sultanate of Oman 1918-1939: Part II (2000), The Sultanate of Oman 1918-1939: Part III (2000), The Sultanate of Oman 1945 Onwards (2000), Britain's Two Wars with Iraq (2003), and Lebanon and Arabism, 1936-1945 (2004).<ref>{{cite book |title=Lebanon and Arabism |publisher=Raghid el-Solh, I.B. Tauris Publishers |date= 2004|url=https://books.google.ae/books?id=49z7AFqIE2IC&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=kazem+solh+ambassador+iraq&source=bl&ots=44hRqnrKx6&sig=Xf5cMa3_RJIZ30Ezad-PXy80RAw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWn8zvyZHbAhXBtBQKHVd7CxcQ6AEIPjAI#v=onepage&q=kazem%20solh%20ambassador%20iraq&f=false}}</ref>
He was a Visiting Fellow at the Institute for Middle Eastern and Islamic Studies at the University of Durham, U.K.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dr. Raghid Kazem El-Solh Profile |publisher=The Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research |date=2018 |url=http://www.ecssr.ac.ae/ECSSR/print/prf.jsp?lang=en&prfId=/Profile/Profiles_1285.xml}}</ref>
He did consultancy work for the UN and other organizations covering Arab regional affairs, democracy, governance, justice, and human rights.
==Personal life== Raghid El-Solh was born on July 7, 1942, in Beirut. He was the son of [[Kazem El-Solh]] and Yesser Kamel El-Solh.
Raghid was married to Camillia Fawzi, an Egyptian/Irish socio-economist independent consultant, who passed away 18 months after him on August 29, 2018. They have a daughter Lina and two grandchildren Harry and Lily.
He was the brother of Hannah, Khaldoun and Nawal El-Solh.
Raghid passed away at the age of 74 on February 1, 2018, in Oxford, U.K. He was buried in Beirut, following a memorial at St Antony's College, Oxford.<ref>{{cite web |title=Raghid El-Solh Obituary |publisher=The Times |date=February 4, 2018 |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/thetimes-uk/obituary.aspx?n=raghid-kazim-el-solh&pid=183948077}}</ref>
==Legacy== The Raghid Kazem El-Solh Travel Grant was established after he passed away to help PhD students registered at the University of Oxford in their research across member states of the League of Arab States, focusing on democracy and governance, justice and human rights, regionalism and parliamentary processes, and other relevant subjects in the politics and international relations of the Arab world.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Raghid Kazim El-Solh Travel Grant |publisher=University of Oxford, Middle East Centre |date=April 13, 2018 |url=https://www.facebook.com/events/1166338490169716/?active_tab=discussion}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.aub.edu.lb/maingate/Documents/Maingate-Spring-2018.pdf ''The Maingate, the American University of Beirut magazine''], Beirut, Lebanon, Spring, 2018. *[http://www.ecssr.ac.ae/ECSSR/print/prf.jsp?lang=en&prfId=/Profile/Profiles_1285.xml ''Dr. Raghid Kazem El-Solh Profile''], The Emirates Center for Strategic Studies and Research, U.A.E., 2018. *[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/thetimes-uk/obituary.aspx?n=raghid-kazim-el-solh&pid=183948077 ''The Times''], London, U.K., February 4, 2018. *[https://www.amazon.com/Books-Raghid-El-Solh/s?ie=UTF8&page=1&rh=n%3A283155%2Cp_27%3ARaghid%20El-Solh ''Amazon, books by Raghid El-Solh''] *[https://www.facebook.com/events/1166338490169716/?active_tab=discussion ''University of Oxford, Middle East Centre''], Oxford, U.K., February, 2018. *[https://books.google.ae/books?id=49z7AFqIE2IC&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=kazem+solh+ambassador+iraq&source=bl&ots=44hRqnrKx6&sig=Xf5cMa3_RJIZ30Ezad-PXy80RAw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWn8zvyZHbAhXBtBQKHVd7CxcQ6AEIPjAI#v=onepage&q=kazem%20solh%20ambassador%20iraq&f=false ''Lebanon and Arabism''], By Raghid el-Solh, I.B. Tauris Publishers, 2004, page 147.

{{Infobox person | name = Raymond Augustin Mailhat | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1862|3|28}} | birth_place = [[Saurat]] ([[Ariège (department)|Ariège]]), [[France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1923|4|22|1862|3|28}} | death_place = [[Montrouge]] ([[Seine (department)|Seine]]), [[France]] | nationality = French | occupation = [[Scientific equipment optician]] | years_active = 1889-1909 | known_for = Telescopes and other precision optical instruments | notable_works =
}} '''Raymond Augustin Jean-Baptiste Mailhat''' (28 March 1862 – 22 April 1923) was a French manufacturer of [[Optical telescope|telescopes]] and precision [[optical instruments]].
== Biography == Raymond Mailhat was born on 28 March 1862 in [[Saurat]] ([[Ariège (department)|Ariège]]), the son of Jean Benjamin Mailhat,<ref name=LdH>[http://www2.culture.gouv.fr/LH/LH135/PG/FRDAFAN83_OL1692016v001.htm Légion d’honneur file, Raymond Augustin Jean Baptiste Mailhat’ cote LH/1692/16.]</ref> an illiterate shoemaker.<ref name=Tobin>[http://www.narit.or.th/en/files/2016JAHHvol19/2016JAHH...19..106T.pdf William Tobin "Evolution of the Foucault-Secretan Reflecting Telescope.” ''Journal of Astronomical History and Heritage'', 19(2), 106–184 (2016).]</ref> After studying under Paul Gautier (1842-1909),<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96422725/f649.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1900, n.p.]</ref> Raymond became the director of the Secrétan company’s optics workshop in Paris on 1 January 1889. In 1894, Mailhat bought part of those workshops and established his own business.<ref name=Tobin /> The Maison Mailhat manufactured a wide variety of equipment for both scientists and amateurs:<ref name=Bulletin1908>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96331256/f763.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1908, p. III]</ref> [[File:Fabra Observatory Refractor.jpg|thumb|Mailhat 38 cm refracting telescope at the [[Fabra Observatory]] (telescope built in 1904)]] * [[Optical telescope|Astronomical]] and [[Camera lens|photographic]] lenses * Mirrors (flat, spherical and parabolic) * [[Equatorial mount]] [[refracting telescope|refractor telescopes]] and [[astrophotography|photographic telescopes]] * [[Meridian circles]] (fixed and portable) * Astronomical and geodesical equipment for scientific missions and explorers * Simple [[Refractor Telescope|refractor]] and [[Equatorial mount|equatorial]] telescopes for amateur [[comet]] hunters * Equipment for [[physicists]] * [[Solar telescope|Coelostats]] * [[Heliostat|Siderostats]] * [[Heliostat|Heliostats]] * Astronomical domes and metallic shelters * Complete installations of [[Astronomical observatory|observatories]] * Instruments for [[geodesy]] and [[meteorology]]
The company furnished optical instruments to the [[Paris Observatory]], the Faculté des Sciences de Paris, the [[Bureau des Longitudes]], the [[Camille Flammarion Observatory]] in Juvisy, the [[Société Astronomique de France]], French government ministries, several observatories in France and in other countries, [[Meteorological Station|meteorological stations]], bridge and road engineers, railroads, and mines. It won a gold medal at the [[Exposition Universelle (1900)|Exposition Universelle in Paris in 1900]].<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96422725/f649.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1900, n.p.]</ref><ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9633648x/f511.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1903, n.p.]</ref><ref name=Bulletin1908 />
Mailhat became a member of the [[Société astronomique de France]] in 1888 (only one year after it was established). At the time when he joined, he was a constructor-mechanic, residing at 5, passage Stanislas, Paris.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9628847g/f20.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1888, p. 14.]</ref> Mailhat served on the society's management council in 1894 (and again in 1912)<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96228325/f174.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1895, p. 158.]</ref><ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96263170/f168.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1916, p. 150.]</ref> Advertisements for his company's telescopes appeared regularly in the pages of the [[L'Astronomie (magazine)|society’s bulletin]].
The Maison Mailhat and its fellow Paris-based competitors the [[Secretan (company)|Secrétan]] and [[Denis Albert Bardou|Bardou]] companies were among the leading French precision optics manufacturers of the early twentieth century. Mailhat telescopes and optical products were widely exported to [[Europe]], the [[United States]] and even further afield.
[[Ferdinand Quénisset]] used Mailhat lenses for early photographs of Mars in 1899 at the [[Camille Flammarion Observatory]] in Juvisy.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9626564b/f194.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1899, p. 178.]</ref>
On 1 April 1908, the company’s offices and workshops moved to 10, rue Emile-Dubois Paris, close to the Paris Observatory.<ref name=Bulletin1908 /> The following year, Mailhat sold his company to Francis Mouronval (1881-1954).<ref name=Tobin /> Mouronval continued to produce and sell telescopes under the Maison Mailhat name for seven years.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9626551q/f360.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1911, p. 332.]</ref> Following Mouronval's mobilisation durign the [[World War II]], he publicly announced in 1916 that the Mailhat-Mouronval company was closed "for the duration of the war". This closure appears to have been definitive.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96263170/f500.item Bulletin de la Societe Astronomique de France, 1916, p. II.]</ref>
During the war, Mailhat served as ‘’Officier de l’administration de 3e classe territorial’’ in the [[Service Technique de l'Aéronautique|Service des fabrications de l'aviation]] (military aircraft manufacturing). For his contribution to the war effort, he received the [[Legion of Honor|Légion d’Honneur]] in 1918.<ref name=LdH />
Mailhat died on 22 April 1923 at his home at 13, rue Boileau in [[Montrouge]] ([[Seine (department)|Seine]]).<ref name=LdH />
== Notable Mailhat instruments == [[File:Mailhat.jpg|thumb|Mailhat equatorial refractor telescope in [[San José Observatory]], Buenos Aires]] * Equatorial refractor of 190 mm diameter in the second astronomical dome of the [[Observatory of the rue Serpente|Observatory of the Société Astronomique de France]] at its former headquarters on rue Serpente in Paris. Mailhat’s telescope was exclusively reserved for scientific research.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k96331256/f759.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1908, p. V.]</ref> * Astro-photographic double equatorial refractor of 380 mm diameter at the [[Fabra Observatory]] in [[Barcelona]].<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9641174b/f513.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1904, 491.]</ref> This telescope was used by [[Josep Comas i Solà]] to observe the moons of [[Mars]], [[Deimos (moon)|Deimos]] and [[Phobos (moon)|Phobos]], in 1909, and to photograph [[Halley’s comet]] in 1910.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9672850g/f533.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1909, p. 497.]</ref><ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9671976r/f355.item Bulletin de la Société Astronomique de France, 1910, p. 327.]</ref> * Meridian circle at the Rouen Popular Observatory.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1986LAstr.100..275G Grillot, S. ″Les instruments des observatoires français au 19e siècle.″ L’Astronomie 1986, Vol. 100, p. 279.]</ref> * Astro-photographic equatorial mount refractors constructed for the Ebro Observatory in [[Tortosa]], [[Spain]] and the Puebla Observatory<ref name=Bulletin1908 /><ref>[https://books.google.fr/books?id=SRdJCAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA215&ots=LKTi5AqDn4&dq=mailhat%20telescope&pg=PA216#v=onepage&q=mailhat&f=false Agustin Udias. Searching the Heavens and the Earth: The History of Jesuit Observatories (Dordrecht, Netherlands: Springer Science & Business Media, 2013), p. 215.]</ref>. * Astro-photographic double equatorial refractor of 127mm diameter at the [[San José Observatory]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. [[File:Lille - observatoire - 20.jpg|thumb|Mailhat refractor at Lille Observatory]] * Equatorial refractor of 325 mm diameter and 6 m focal length at the [[:fr:Observatoire de Lille|Lille Observatory]].<ref>[http://astronomie.univ-lille1.fr/Patrimoine/Presentation/ Observatoire de l’Université de Lille]</ref><ref>[http://astroequatoriales.free.fr/spip.php?article27 AstroEquatoriales "Lille 34."]</ref>
==Honors and awards==
* 1906 – [[Société astronomique de France#Awards|Prix des Dames]] by the Société astronomique de France<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9639977j/f222.item Bulletin de la Societe Astronomique de France, 1906, p. 210.]</ref> * 1911 – [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques|Officier de l’Instruction publique]] by the [[Ministry of National Education (France)|Ministry of Education]]<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9626551q/f263.item Bulletin de la Societe Astronomique de France, 1911, p. 237.]</ref> * 1911 – Founding Member (Membre Fondateur) of the Société astronomique de France because of his donation of many valuable telescopes to the society over the years.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9626551q/f219.item Bulletin de la Societe Astronomique de France, 1911, p. 195.]</ref> * 1918 – Chevalier of the [[Legion of Honor|Légion d’Honneur]]<ref name=LdH />

{{EngvarB|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Rhoda Weeks–Brown | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1967}} | birth_place = [[Cape Palmas]], [[Liberia]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = '''[[Howard University]]'''
{{small|([[Economics|Bachelor of Arts in Economics]])}}
'''[[Harvard University]]'''
{{small|([[Juris Doctor]])}} | occupation = [[Economist]] & [[Lawyer]] | years_active = 1991 — present | nationality = [[Liberia]]n | ethnicity = | citizenship = [[Liberia]] | residence = [[Washington, DC]], United States | known_for = [[Law]] | networth = | home_town = [[Cape Palmas]], Maryland County, [[Liberia]] | title = General Counsel and Head of the Legal Department at the [[International Monetary Fund]] |religion = }} '''Rhoda Weeks–Brown''' is a [[Liberia]]n [[economist]] and [[lawyer]], who currently serves as the designated next General Counsel and Director of the Legal Department, at the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF). She was appointed to that position by the IMF Managing Director, [[Christine Lagarde]], on 30 July 2018. Weeks–Brown, who has been serving as Deputy General Counsel at the IMF, assumes her new position on Monday 17 September 2018.{{cite web|access-date=1 August 2018 |date=31 July 2018 |publisher=Corporate Counsel via [[Law.com]] |last=Reisinger |first=Sue |location=New York City | url=https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2018/07/31/international-monetary-fund-names-rhoda-weeks-brown-as-next-general-counsel/?slreturn=20180701121631 |title=International Monetary Fund Names Rhoda Weeks-Brown as Next General Counsel}} ==Background and education== A native of the [[West Africa]]n country of [[Liberia]], she is the daughter of the late Rocheforte Lafayette Weeks, the lawyer/politician who served as the president of the [[University of Liberia]] and Fannie Elizabeth Thompson-Goll, of Maryland County, Liberia.{{cite web|access-date=1 August 2018 | url=https://www.liberianobserver.com/news/rhoda-weeks-brown-appointed-to-top-legal-post-at-imf/ |title=Rhoda Weeks-Brown Appointed to Top Legal Post at IMF |date=1 August 2018 | newspaper=[[Liberian Observer|Daily Observer]] |author=Webmaster Administrator |location=Monrovia}} She studied at [[Howard University]], in Washington, DC, graduating with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[Economics]]. In 1991, along with the 44th President of the United States, [[Barack Obama]], she was awarded the [[Juris Doctor]] degree, by the [[Harvard University Law School]]. ==Career== Following her law degree studies, Weeks-Brown worked for several years at the law firm of [[Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom]], specializing in financial institutions regulatory matters, while there.{{cite web|url=http://www.un.org/esa/ffd/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/20120919_Biographies.pdf |format=PDF | title=Expert Group Meeting On Sovereign Debt Restructuring: Biographies of Speakers: Rhoda Weeks-Brown |date=19 September 2012 |publisher=[[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth Secretariat]] | location=Marlborough House, Pall Mall, London |access-date=1 August 2018 |author=Commonwealth Secretariat}} She joined the legal department at the International Monetary Fund in 1997. Over the years, she rose through the ranks to become Deputy Legal Counsel in 2010. She then joined the Fund’s Communications Department in 2012 as Deputy Director. She is expected to replace Sean Hagan, who has led the legal team at the IMF since 1990. He i expected to join academia, when he retires from the IMF at the end of October 2017.{{cite web|title=IMF General Counsel Sean Hagan to Retire | url=https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2018/06/18/pr18242-imf-general-counsel-sean-hagan-to-retire |access-date=1 August 2018 |date=18 June 2018 |publisher=[[International Monetary Fund]] | author=International Monetary Fund |location=Washington, DC}} ==Other considerations== Rhonda Weeks-Brown is a member of the [[Board of Directors]] of [http://talentnomics.org/about-talentnomics/ Talentnomics Inc.], an international [[non-profit]] that aims to increase women leadership worldwide and to eliminate the [[Gender pay gap|gender gap]] in hiring and remuneration.{{cite web|date=1 August 2018 | url=http://talentnomics.org/board-members-talentnomics-inc/ | title=Board Members At TalentNomics, Inc. |access-date=1 August 2018 |publisher=TalentNomics, Inc. |author=TalentNomics | location=New York City}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2018/07/30/pr18321-imf-lagarde-appoints-rhoda-weeks-brown-as-general-counsel-of-the-imf IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde Appoints Rhoda Weeks-Brown as General Counsel of the IMF and Director of the Legal Department] As of 30 July 2018. {{DEFAULTSORT:Weeks-Browwn, Rhoda}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Liberian people]] [[Category:Liberian women]] [[Category:Liberian lawyers]] [[Category:Howard University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:Liberian economists]] [[Category:Liberian diplomats]] [[Category:Liberian women lawyers]] [[Category:Americo-Liberian people]]

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=June 2017}} {{notability|Biographies|date=June 2017}} {{peacock|date=June 2017}} }} '''Dr. Selwa Al-Hazzaa''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: سلوى الهزّاع) is a [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] [[ophthalmologist]] at [[King Faisal Specialist Hospital]] as the head of the ophthalmology department. She is considered{{by whom|date=May 2018}} as one of the most influential personalities in [[Saudi Arabia]], and the [[Arab World]] in general. She is also considered{{by whom|date=May 2018}} to be a pioneer for Saudi women, as she is one of the first Saudi women to achieve international success academically and professionally. On January 11, 2013, as per Royal Decree from King Abdullah, Al-Hazzaa became one of the first ever female members of the Saudi Arabia Shoura Council. <ref>http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2013/01/11/259881.html</ref>
==Education and life== At a young age she moved with her family from [[Riyadh, Saudi Arabia]], to [[Tucson, Arizona]]. She studied at [[Tucson High]], then moved back with her family to [[Riyadh, Saudi Arabia]] to complete high school studies.
She later enrolled at [[King Saud University]] to study medicine. She married a Saudi and moved with him to [[Washington, DC]] because he worked at the [[Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia in Washington, DC]]. She continued to pursue her studies at [[Johns Hopkins University]] and obtained her residence at [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]] in three years.{{fact|date=May 2018}} After that, she moved back to Riyadh to work at [[King Faisal Specialist Hospital]]. She published many papers, but her most important paper was DUANES, which specialized in genetically inherited eye diseases in Saudi Arabia.{{fact|date=May 2018}} In 1997, she became the first female department head in King Faisal Specialist Hospital, as she became the head of the ophthalmology department.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
==References== <references/>

'''Sara Benetowa''', later known as '''Sula Benet''' (1903–1982), was a [[Poland|Polish]] anthropologist of the 20th century who studied Polish and [[Judaic]] customs and traditions.
==Biography== Born in Poland, Benet was fascinated with peasant culture of Poland since her early youth. This interest eventually led her to enroll as a student of literature and philosophy in the Faculty of Humanities in the [[University of Warsaw]], graduating with a degree in [[anthropology]]. Upon receiving her degree in 1935, she attended graduate school at [[Columbia University]], where she received her [[doctorate]] in 1944. Also at this time (1936) she first made known at a seminar in Warsaw her theory that "calamus" in the Bible is hemp.<ref>Sula Benetova 1936 Le chanvre dans les croyances et les coutumes populaires. Comtes Rendus de Séances de la Société des Sciences et des Lettres de Varsovie XXVII.</ref>
==Cannabis research== Benet discovered that the Biblical plants or spices "kaneh" ([[Book of Ezekiel|Ez.]] 27:19; [[Book of Isaiah|Is.]] 43:24; [[Song of Songs|Ct.]] 4:14), "kaneh ha-tob" ([[Book of Jeremiah|Je.]] 6:20), and "kaneh-bosem" ([[Book of Exodus|Ex.]] 30:23), which are usually translated as "sweet [[Acorus calamus|calamus]]" or "sweet [[Arundo donax|cane]]", were actually [[hemp]]. "Kaneh-bosem" was an ingredient of the holy [[anointing]] oil:
{{Quote|text=30:22 Moreover the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 30:23 Take thou also unto thee principal spices, of pure myrrh five hundred shekels, and of sweet cinnamon half so much, even two hundred and fifty shekels, and of sweet calamus (Hebrew '''kaneh-bosem''') two hundred and fifty shekels, 30:24 And of cassia five hundred shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary, and of oil olive an hin: 30:25 And thou shalt make it an oil of holy ointment, an ointment compound after the art of the apothecary: it shall be an holy anointing oil.|title=[[Book of Exodus|Ex.]] 30:22-25 | source=[[King James Version]]}}
This ingredient is, however, not mentioned amongst those prescribed in Ex. 30:34, from which the incense ([[ketoret]]) for the Temple was to be prepared.<ref>{{citation | author=[[Ernst Friedrich Karl Rosenmüller]] | title=The Mineralogy and Botany of the Bible | series=The Biblical Cabinet | volume=27 | publisher=Clark | year=1840 | page=190 | url=https://archive.org/details/mineralogybotany27rose}}</ref>
According to [[Julius Wellhausen]]'s documentary hypothesis, Ex. 30:23 belongs to a priestly (P) source, composed sometime between the 8th and the mid-6th century B.C.<ref>{{citation | editor=[[Francis Brown (theologian)|Francis Brown]] | entry=קָנֶה | title=Hebrew and English Lexicon | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1906 | page=889b | url=https://archive.org/details/hebrewenglishlex00browuoft}}</ref><ref>{{citation | author1=Richard Elliott Friedman | author2=Shawna Dolansky Overton | author3=Louis Isaac Rabinowitz | entry=PENTATEUCH | title=[[Encyclopaedia Judaica]] | edition=2nd | volume=15 | year=2007 | publisher=Gale | pages=730–753 | isbn=0-02-865943-0}}</ref>
Based on similar words in cognate languages ([[Sanskrit language|Sanskrit]] śana, [[Akkadian language|Assyrian]] qunnabu, [[Persian language|Persian]] kenab, [[Arabic language|Arabic]] kanab) Benet concluded that "kaneh" and "kaneh-bosem" refer to hemp. In many ancient languages, including Hebrew, the root "kan" had a double meaning, both hemp and reed. The error originated from the oldest Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible, [[Septuagint]], in the third century B.C., where the terms "kaneh" and "kaneh-bosem" had been (mis)translated as "sweet kalamos". In the many Bible translations that followed, including [[Martin Luther]]'s, the same error was repeated. Benet further claimed that the [[Scythians]], who were described by [[Herodotus]] as ritual hemp users in the fifth century B.C., were at least one millennium older than has been previously assumed.<ref>{{citation | editor1=Vera Rubin | editor2=Lambros Comitas | title=Cannabis and Culture | author=Sula Benet | contribution=Early Diffusions and Folk Uses of Hemp | publisher=Moutan | year=1975 | pages=39–49 | url=https://www.xn--4dbcyzi5a.com/wp-content/PDF/EARLY-DIFFUSION-AND-FOLK-USES-OF-HEMP-SULA-BENET.pdf}}</ref>
Sulah Benet's claim has found increased support in the academic community among lexicographers and botanists. The standard reference lexicons of Biblical Hebrew, and reference works on Hebrew Bible plants by scholars such as University of Jerusalem botanist [[Michael Zohary]] mention Benet's suggestion, while others argue the word refers to an either different species of hemp or a different plant entirely. [[Olof Celsius|Celsius]] (Hierobotanicon) has suggested [[sweet flag]] ([[Acorus calamus]]), which grows in Egypt, Judaea, and Syria, containing in its stalk a soft white pith with an agreeable aromatic smell, and forming an ingredient of the richest perfumes.<ref>{{citation | editor=[[John McClintock (theologian)|John McClintock]] | editor2=[[James Strong (theologian)|James Strong]] | entry=Calamus | title=[[Cyclopaedia of Biblical, Theological and Ecclesiastical Literature]] | volume=2 | publisher=Harper & Brothers | year=1891 | page=17}}</ref> [[John Forbes Royle|Royle]] identified the "sweet cane" ([[King James Version|A.V.]]) of Scripture (Is. 43:24; Je. 6:20) with the [[Andropogon calamus]], a plant extensively cultivated in India, from which an oil, deemed to be the famous [[spikenard]] of antiquity, is extracted.<ref>{{citation | editor=[[John McClintock (theologian)|John McClintock]] | editor2=[[James Strong (theologian)|James Strong]] | entry=Cane | title=[[Cyclopaedia of Biblical, Theological and Ecclesiastical Literature]] | volume=2 | publisher=Harper & Brothers | year=1891 | pages=72–73}}</ref> According to [[Pierre Edmond Boissier|Boissier]] (Flora Orientalis), "kaneh" was the common marsh reed, [[Arundo donax]] [[Linnaeus|L]].<ref>{{citation | editor=[[Isidore Singer]] et al. | author1=[[Emil G. Hirsch]] | title=[[Jewish Encyclopedia]] | entry=REED | volume=10 | year=1906 | page=346b}}</ref> Some biblical scholars and botanists believe that the qaneh is probably [[sugarcane]].<ref>{{citation | author=Ernest L. Abel | title=Marihuana, the first twelve thousand years | year=1980 | publisher=Springer | page=27 | url=http://files.meetup.com/18500005/Abel.%20marihuana%20the%20first%20twelve%20thousand%20years.pdf | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310021048/http://files.meetup.com/18500005/Abel.%20marihuana%20the%20first%20twelve%20thousand%20years.pdf | archivedate=2016-03-10 | df= }}</ref>
In Hebrew, "kanebas", "kanebiys", "kanebos" ({{hebrew|קַנְבָּס, קַנְבִּיס, קַנְבּוֹס}}), derived from Greek "kannabis", first appear in the [[Mishnah]] ([[Kil'ayim (tractate)|Kilayim]] 2:5; 5:8; 9:1, 5, 7). The [[Jerusalem Talmud]] (Kilayim 9:5, 32d) notes that while in mishnaic times hemp was an important commodity because of the difficulty of cultivating linen, in the days of the [[Amoraim]] linen replaced it.<ref>{{citation | author=[[Marcus Jastrow]] | entry=קַנְבָּס, קַנְבִּיס, קַנְבּוֹס | title=A Dictionary of the Targumim, the Talmud Babli and Yerushalmi, and the Midrashic Literature | publisher=Luzac | year=1903 | volume=2 | page=1388b | url=https://archive.org/details/dictionaryoftarg02jastuoft}}</ref><ref>{{citation | author=Jehuda Feliks | entry=HEMP | title=[[Encyclopaedia Judaica]] | edition=2nd | volume=5 | year=2007 | publisher=Gale | page=805 | isbn=0-02-865933-3}}</ref>
==Works== * ''Konopie w wierzeniach i zwyczajach ludowych'' (1936) * ''Song, Dance, and Customs of Peasant Poland'' (1951) * ''Festive recipes and festival menus'' (1957) * ''Riddles of many lands'' Carl Withers, Sula Benet (1956) * ''Early Diffusion and Folk Uses of Hemp'' (1967) * ''Abkhasians: the long-living people of the Caucasus'' (1974) * ''How to live to be 100: the life-style of the people of the Caucasus'' (1976)
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Booth, M. (2003). ''Cannabis: A History''. Doubleday. {{ISBN|1409084892}}. {{Cannabis and Judaism}} {{Authority control}}

{{more footnotes|date=February 2013}} '''Valeriy Zaporozhan''' is ex-[[Rector (academia)|rector]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://moz.gov.ua/article/news/moz-vidstoroniv-rektora-odeskogo-meduniversitetu-zaporozhana-vm|title=Ministry of Health of Ukraine|last=|first=|date=МОЗ відсторонив ректора Одеського медуніверситету Запорожана В.М.|work=|access-date=}}</ref> of [[Odessa State Medical University]] ([[Ukraine]]), Ukrainian researcher. His initial specialization was obstetrics and gynaecology, which further broadened to [[cryosurgery]] and [[endoscopy]], [[immunology]], [[reproductive medicine]], [[genetic medicine]], [[stem cells]], and bioethics. He also developed the concept of [[nooethics]] - a further specialization of bioethics in the conditions of [[noosphere]].
== Career == In 1971, Zaporozhan graduated from [[Odessa State Medical University|Pirogov Odessa Medical Institute]]. He was employed as senior laboratory officer, assistant professor, associate professor, and full professor. Since 1986, he heads the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of the Odessa State Medical University. Starting from 1994 and until 17 July 2018 <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://moz.gov.ua/article/news/moz-vidstoroniv-rektora-odeskogo-meduniversitetu-zaporozhana-vm|title=Ministry of Health of Ukraine|last=|first=|date=МОЗ відсторонив ректора Одеського медуніверситету Запорожана В.М.|work=|access-date=}}</ref> he held the heading position ([[Rector (academia)|Rector]]) of the Odessa State Medical University.
== Scientific Degrees == Since 1976 — [[Kandidat Nauk]] (Medicine), since 1982 — [[Doktor Nauk]] (Medicine), since 1986 — [[Full Professor]].
In 1997 he became the associate member of [[Academy of Medical Sciences of Ukraine]], progressing to full member of the Academy in 2000. In 2002 he was elected a member of Presidium of the Academy.
== References == {{Reflist}} * http://odmu.edu.ua/index.php?v=103 (Ukrainian) * http://zaporozhan.name (Russian)

[[File:Walter Evans-Wentz and Lama Kazi Dawa Samdup photographed circa 1919.jpg|thumb|Walter Evans-Wentz and [[Kazi Dawa Samdup|Lama Kazi Dawa Samdup]] photographed circa 1919]] '''Walter Yeeling Evans-Wentz''' (February 2, 1878 – July 17, 1965) was an American anthropologist and writer who was a pioneer in the study of [[Tibetan Buddhism]], and in transmission of Tibetan Buddhism to the Western world, most known for publishing an early English translation of ''[[Bardo Thodol|The Tibetan Book of the Dead]]'' in 1927. Today, Evans-Wentz is best known for four texts translated from the Tibetan: ''The Tibetan Book of the Dead'' (1927), ''Tibet's Great Yogi Milarepa'' (1928), ''Tibetan Yoga and Secret Doctrines'' (1935), and ''The Tibetan Book of the Great Liberation'' (1954).
==Early life and background== Walter was born as '''Walter Yeeling Wentz''' in [[Trenton, New Jersey]] in 1878. His father Christopher Wentz (1836 - February 4, 1921) - born in Weissengen, Baden, Germany - had emigrated to America with his parents in 1846.<ref>https://lamesahistory.com/wp-content/uploads/LO_222_2001.pdf - "Wentz-Park House Landmarked, A Designated Historic Site" in ''Lookout Avenue'', Volume 22, Number 2 (Autumn 2001), p. 6 (La Mesa Historical Society)</ref> At the turn of the century (1900) Christopher was a real estate developer in Pablo Beach, Florida. Walter's mother (and Christopher's 1st wife) - Mary Evans Cook (died 1898) - was of Irish heritage. Christopher and Mary were married on August 11, 1862 in Trenton, Mercer County, New Jersey. Christopher's 2nd wife (they were married on June 4, 1900 in Duval County, Florida) was Olivia F. Bradford (1863-1949). Walter had two brothers and two sisters.<ref name=david>{{cite web| title = The Hermit Who Owned His Mountain: A Profile of W.Y. Evans Wentz |publisher= Tricycle| url = http://www.tricycle.com/ancestors/the-hermit-who-owned-his-mountain-a-profile-wy-evans-wentz|author=David Guy| accessdate = 2013-08-30}}</ref>{{dead link|date=November 2018}} Though initially a Baptist, Walter's father had turned to [[spiritualism]] and [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]].<ref name="Oldmeadow135"/> As a teenager, Walter read [[Madame Blavatsky]]'s ''[[Isis Unveiled]]'' and ''[[The Secret Doctrine]]'' in his father's library, and became interested in the teachings of Theosophy and the occult.<ref name="Lopez49">[[#Lo|Lopez, p. 49]]</ref> Subsequently, at the turn of century, Walter moved to [[San Diego]], California to join his father's profession, but also because it was close to [[Lomaland]], the American headquarters for the [[Theosophical Society]],<ref name=david/> which he joined in 1901.<ref name="Lopez52"/>
At age 24 Evans-Wentz went to [[Stanford University]], where he studied religion, philosophy, and history and was deeply influenced by visitors [[William James]] and [[W. B. Yeats]].<ref name="Oldmeadow135"/> He went on to receive B.A. and M.A degrees.<ref name=david/> He then studied [[Celtic mythology]] and folklore at [[Jesus College, Oxford]]<ref name="sutin262">Sutin 2006, pg. 262</ref> (1907). He performed ethnographic fieldwork collecting [[fairy]] folklore in Wales, Scotland, Ireland, Cornwall, Brittany, and the Isle of Man. In 1911 Evans-Wentz published his degree thesis as a book, ''The Fairy-Faith in Celtic Countries''.<ref name=david/><ref>{{cite web | title = Evans-Wentz, W. Y. (Walter Yeeling), 1878-1965:Biographical History|publisher=University of Virginia|url =http://socialarchive.iath.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=evans-wentz-w-y-walter-yeeling-1878-1965-cr.xml| accessdate = 2013-08-30}}</ref> While at Oxford, he added his mother's Welsh surname [[Evans (surname)|Evans]] to his name, being known henceforth as Evans-Wentz.<ref name="Lopez52">[[#Lo|Lopez, p. 52]]</ref>
==Career== At Oxford, Evans-Wentz met archaeologist and British Army officer [[T.E. Lawrence]], who advised him to travel to the [[Orient]].<ref name="Oldmeadow135"/>
Thereafter, funded by his rental properties in Florida,<ref name="Lopez52"/> he started travelling extensively, spending time in [[Mexico]], [[Europe]], and the Far East. He spent the years of the [[First World War]] in [[Egypt]]. He boarded a ship from [[Port Said]], Egypt for [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]] (then Ceylon).<ref name="Oldmeadow136"/> Here he started studying the history, customs and religious traditions of the country,<ref name="Oldmeadow136"/> and also collected a large number of important [[Pali]] manuscripts, which were later donated to Stanford University. Next in 1918, he travelled across [[India]], covering important religious sites, "seeking wise men of the east". He met spiritual figures like [[Yogananda]], [[J. Krishnamurti]], [[Paul Brunton]], [[Ramana Maharishi]], [[Sri Krishna Prem]] and [[Alfred Sorensen|Shunyata]]. He also visited the [[Theosophical Society Adyar]], where he met [[Annie Besant]] and Swami Shyamananda Giri (1911-1971).<ref>Swami Shyamananda Giri (May 4, 1911 - August 28, 1971) - AKA Yogacharya Binay Narayan. His name at birth was Binayendra Narayan Dubey.</ref><ref name="Lopez52"/>
Finally he reached [[Darjeeling]] in 1919;<ref name="Oldmeadow136">[[#Ol|Oldmeadow, p. 136]]</ref> there he encountered Tibetan religious texts firsthand, when he acquired a Tibetan manuscript of [[Karma Lingpa]]'s ''Liberation through Hearing during the Intermediate State'' (or ''[[Bardo Thodol]]'') from Major Campbell, a British officer who had just returned from Tibet. He next met [[Lama Kazi Dawa-Samdup]] (1868–1922), an English teacher and headmaster at Maharaja's Boys School, in [[Gangtok]], [[Sikkim]]. Samdup had been with [[13th Dalai Lama]] during the latter's exile years in India in 1910; more importantly for Evans-Wentz, he had already worked as a translator with [[Alexandra David-Néel]], the Belgian-French explorer, travel writer, and Buddhist convert, and Sir [[John Woodroffe]], noted British Orientalist.<ref name="Lopez52"/><ref name="Oldmeadow136"/>
For the next two months, Evans-Wentz spent morning hours before the opening of the school with Samdup working on the text. During this period, they worked out the origins of what was to become ''The Tibetan Book of the Dead''. Evans-Wentz soon left for the Swami Satyananda's [[ashram]], where he was practicing yoga. Samdup meanwhile was appointed as a lecturer at the [[University of Calcutta]], in the same year, and died in Calcutta three years later, long before the book could be finally published.<ref name="Lopez53">[[#Lo|Lopez, p. 53]]</ref>
In 1927, ''The Tibetan Book of the Dead'' was published by [[Oxford University Press]]. Evans-Wentz chose the title "Book of the Dead" because it reminded him of the [[Book of the Dead|Egyptian ''Book of the Dead'']]. For Westerners, the book would become a principal reference on Tibetan Buddhism.<ref name="Oldmeadow135"/> Evans-Wentz credited himself only as the compiler and editor of these volumes; the actual translation was performed by Tibetan Buddhists, primarily Lama Kazi Dawa-Samdup. Evans-Wentz's interpretations and organization of this Tibetan material is [[Hermeneutics|hermeneutically]] controversial, being influenced by preconceptions he brought to the subject from Theosophy and other metaphysical schools.<ref>Donald S. Lopez, Jr. ''The Tibetan Book of the Dead: A Biography,'' Princeton University Press, 2011.</ref>
This book was followed by ''Tibet's Great Yogi Milarepa'' (1928), also based on Samdup's translations. Evans-Wentz was a practitioner of the religions he studied. He became Dawa-Samdup's "disciple" (E-W's term), wore robes, and ate a simple [[vegetarian]] diet.<ref name="sutin263">Sutin 2006, pg. 263</ref> In 1935, he met [[Ramana Maharshi]] and went to Darjeeling, where he employed three translators, Sikkimese of Tibetan descent, to translate another text which was published as ''Tibetan Yoga and Secret Doctrines'' (1935).<ref name="Lopez54"/>
Evans-Wentz intended to settle permanently in India, but was compelled by [[World War II]] to return to the U.S. There he would publish ''The Tibetan Book of the Great Liberation'' in 1954. A final work, ''[[Cuchama]] and Sacred Mountains'' (1989), was published posthumously.
In 1946, he wrote the preface to Yogananda's well known ''[[Autobiography of a Yogi]]'', that introduced both Yogananda and himself to wider audiences in a book which has been in print for over sixty-five years and translated into at least thirty-four languages. Evans-Wentz remains best known his lasting legacy to [[Tibetology]].<ref name="Oldmeadow135">[[#Ol|Oldmeadow, p. 135]]</ref><ref>'Walter Evans-Wentz' in: Forbes, Andrew ; Henley, David (2013). ''The Illustrated Tibetan Book of the Dead''. Chiang Mai: Cognoscenti Books. B00BCRLONM</ref>
==Later years and death== Evans-Wentz remained a [[Theosophist]] for the rest of his life, writing articles for Theosophical publications and provided financial support to the [[Maha Bodhi Society]], [[Self-Realization Fellowship]], and the Theosophical Society.<ref name="Lopez54">[[#Lo|Lopez, p. 54]]</ref> He lived for 23 years at the Keystone Hotel in [[San Diego]].<ref name="Lopez54"/><ref name="Oldmeadow137">[[#Ol|Oldmeadow, p. 137]]</ref> Evans-Wentz spent his last months at Yogananda's [[Self-Realization Fellowship]] in [[Encinitas, California]]<ref name="Lopez54"/> and died in July 1965. His ''Tibetan Book of the Dead'' was read at his funeral.<ref name="sutin 267">Sutin 2006, pg. 267</ref>
==Legacy== The Department of Religious Studies at [[Stanford University]] has hosted "The Evans-Wentz Lectureship in Asian Philosophy, Religion, and Ethics" since 1969, funded by a bequest from Evans-Wentz.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scbs.stanford.edu/ARC/archives/evans-wentz.html|title=Stanford Evans-Wentz Lectureship|author=|date=|website=stanford.edu}}</ref>{{dead link|date=November 2018}}
